properties.Field2: This city in southeastern Iowa was a major stop on the Underground Railroad. It had a significant abolitionist community, and several safe houses were established here.
properties.display_name: Burlington, Des Moines County, Iowa, 52601, United States

properties.Field2: The state capital, Des Moines, also played a role in the Underground Railroad. Some of the early settlers in Des Moines were abolitionists, and they provided assistance to runaway slaves.
properties.display_name: Des Moines, Polk County, Iowa, United States

properties.Field2: This Mississippi River town was a key location for fugitive slaves. It had a sizable abolitionist population and was considered a safe haven for those seeking freedom.
This town in eastern Iowa was known for its Quaker community, which was strongly opposed to slavery. The Quakers in West Liberty were active in assisting runaway slaves.
properties.display_name: West Liberty, Muscatine County, Iowa, 52776, United States

properties.Field2: Located in the northeast corner of the state, Dubuque was another city with Underground Railroad activity. It was a prominent stop for fugitives moving northward.
properties.display_name: Dubuque, Dubuque County, Iowa, United States

properties.Field2: Situated along the Mississippi River, Davenport had several known Underground Railroad stations. The river served as a natural barrier, and many slaves attempted to cross it to reach freedom.
properties.display_name: Davenport, Scott County, Iowa, United States

properties.Field2: Tabor was a unique community in Iowa known for its strong anti-slavery stance. It was founded by abolitionists and was a haven for fugitive slaves.
properties.display_name: Tabor, Fremont County, Iowa, 51653, United States
